Content: USDA state-by-state show top states for Federal local food investments include Kentucky, Wisconsin, Mississippi, Texas and Alabama  Release & Contact Info  Press Release  Release No. .15  Contact:Office of Communications 720-  WASHINGTON, June 30, — Today, the Obama Administration invited communities to participate in Local Foods, Local Places, a federal initiative providing direct technical support to build strong local food systems as part of a community's emerging economic action plans. Under this effort, a team of agricultural, transportation, public health, environmental, and regional economic experts will work directly with local communities to spur local economic growth and improve the quality of life for all residents.Local food sales topped $11.7 billion in according to industry estimates, underscoring the economic benefit that a local food system can offer a community. As part of today's announcement, the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) released an updated state-by-state "Made in Rural America" report illustrating the impact of USDA's investments in rural communities, including local food. USDA has invested more than $800 million in more than 29,100 local and regional food businesses and infrastructure projects over the past six years."These state by state analyses reaffirm that local food is rapidly growing from a niche market to an integrated system recognized for its economic boost to communities across the country," said Secretary Vilsack. "Local food creates new market opportunities for farmers, brings fresh meals into schools and other institutions, expands healthy food access to underserved communities, and builds infrastructure needed to support ranchers and other meat processors. By investing in projects at the local level, this Administration is encouraging growth in this sector and creating new opportunities for families who live in rural America."This is the second year of the Local Foods, Local Places program. In , 26 rural and urban communities participated in the program to create year-round, downtown markets featuring foods from local farmers; establish retail outlets to help revitalize small-town main streets; build centrally located community kitchens or food hubs to aggregate and market local foods; support business incubators to help entrepreneurs start food-related businesses on main streets; enhance public spaces for people to walk or bicycle to farmers markets and local restaurants; assist schoolchildren to grow their own food and make healthy local food accessible to families, including via SNAP benefits; and develop community gardens in walkable, transit-accessible places.Technical support teams through Local Foods, Local Places helped Osceola, Arkansas (pop 7,700) develop a new health foods cooking curriculum for the local school district, create a plan for a new downtown farmers market and implement infrastructure improvement efforts; guided North Little Rock, Arkansas (population 62,000) to enhance the livability of an emerging neighborhood though a new food hub; and worked with Wheeling, West Virginia (pop 28,000) to revitalize underused property into a community orchard, multi-use food facility, and a mobile market.Local Foods, Local Places is a partnership between USDA, the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), the Department of Transportation (DoT), the Appalachian Regional Commission (ARC), and the Delta Regional Authority (DRA). The effort is part of the White House Rural Council's "Rural Impact" effort to improve quality of life and upward mobility for kids and families in rural and tribal communities. Together, the agencies are investing $800,000 to support this round of assistance. Application and deadlines are available on line.Since , USDA has invested in 29,100 food hubs, small scale processing, farmers market and other opportunities in local food across all 50 states and the US territories. This includes USDA investments in the local food sector through over 12,000 microloans, smaller loans of up to $50,000 for small-scale producers who often sell products locally; and over 13,000 high tunnels, low-cost covered structures that extend the growing season and make locally-grown products available later into the year.Among the top ten states with federally funded local food projects are Kentucky, Wisconsin, Mississippi, Texas, Alabama, Missouri, Minnesota, West Virginia, Iowa, and Michigan. Five of these states (Kentucky, Mississippi, Alabama, Texas and West Virginia) are part USDA's StrikeForce Initiative for Rural Growth and Opportunity which coordinates USDA assistance in the Nation's most economically challenged rural areas.Many of these projects can be found on the Know Your Farmer, Know Your Food Compass. Searchable by state, zip code, project type and funding program, the Know Your Farmer, Know Your Food Compass maps federal local food investments made by USDA and 10 other federal agencies between fiscal years -. The Compass is part of the USDA's Know Your Farmer, Know Your Food Initiative. Secretary Vilsack has identified local and regional food systems as one of the four pillars of rural economic development, along with production agriculture, the bio-based economy, and natural resources and conservation.The state by state fact sheets are available at www.usda.gov/opportunities. Each state factsheet highlights specific USDA investments in local food as well investments in rural businesses, manufacturing, energy, water and other infrastructure development. They also outline how USDA is helping rural communities attract businesses and families by investing in housing and broadband. is an equal opportunity provider and employer. To file a complaint of discrimination, write: USDA, Office of the Assistant Secretary for Civil Rights, Office of Adjudication, Independence Ave., SW, Washington, DC 0- or call 632- (Toll-free Customer Service), 877- (Local or Federal relay), 377- (Relay voice users).
Question: What is the main goal of the Local Foods, Local Places program initiated by the Obama Administration?
True Answer: The main goal of the Local Foods, Local Places program is to provide direct technical support to build strong local food systems as part of a community's emerging economic action plans, with the aim of spurring local economic growth and improving quality of life for residents.
Generated Answer: The main goal of the Local Foods, Local Places program initiated by the Obama Administration was to support communities in developing and implementing plans that connect local food systems with economic development strategies. The program aimed to help communities: 1. Develop a comprehensive plan that connects local food systems with other community assets (such as historic districts, public spaces, or natural resources) 2. Strengthen their local economies by supporting food-related businesses 3. Improve the health and well-being of residents through access to fresh, locally grown foods The program provided technical assistance and funding to communities to help them achieve these goals.

Content: New Tools Bring Lenders to the Table for Local, Regional Food Enterprises  Open any food magazine these days and you’re bound to find a profile of the latest locavore start-up turning cream and cantaloupe into craft popsicles or maple sap into a whole new category of bottled beverages.  As consumer demand for local foods continues to climb like pole beans, venture capitalists are scouring this sector in search of the next hot investment. USDA has long been investing in this space too, for the good of rural economies. And now we’re unveiling a new online interactive training to help other funders understand the work of regional food enterprises that are connecting local producers with local markets, and why they might want to invest in a piece of this pie.  Lillian Salerno, Deputy Under Secretary, USDA Rural Development  Posted in  Food and Nutrition  Farming  Rural  USDA Results  May 11,   Respond to this story

Content: Foreign Agricultural Service Administrator in  Trade  Oct 22,  Trade visitors sample a variety of cheeses at the Rogue Creamery stand in the USA Pavilion. Rogue Creamery, an artisan cheese company, is dedicated to sustainability and the art and tradition of making the world's finest handmade cheese. Earlier this week I traveled to Paris to attend the 24th edition of the Salon International d’Alimentation (SIAL). This 5-day event is one of the largest international food and beverage trade exhibitions in the world, attracting 5,500 exhibitors and over 147,000 trade-only visitors representing 188 countries. I was very impressed by the wide variety of U.S. products on display and by the number of participating countries. For nearly 20 years, the United States has participated in SIAL Paris. This year’s USA Pavilion at SIAL was the largest to date, with some 140 exhibitors occupying over 2,700 square meters. SIAL offers U.S. food exporters the opportunity to test products and meet with European as well as other international traders and industry professionals. Clearly, this is a major factor for the large U.S. presence. One of my primary reasons for attending the show was to meet face to face with U.S. Cooperators, exhibitors, and importers from Europe and other regions, as well as industry leaders. I had the pleasure of talking with many small- and medium-sized companies and Cooperator groups who expressed their appreciation of our programs and services, including American Food Service, Head Country Food Products, Rogue Creamery, U.S. Meat Export Federation, USA Poultry and Egg Export Council, and representatives from the state regional trade groups (SRTG), just to name a few. Tuesday night’s SRTG-hosted trade reception, as well as an industry reception, was yet another wonderful opportunity to talk with Pavilion exhibitors and trade visitors. Reception guests included buyer groups from North Africa and the Middle East recruited by our FAS Field offices. The European Union (EU) is a major trading partner for the United States. The EU is America’s fifth largest market for agricultural and food products. France alone imports nearly $1 billion of U.S. farm goods annually. However, the scope of SIAL extended beyond the EU, reaching importers from all corners of the world. Building a market presence is sometimes a long process, and participation in these types of trade shows introduces foreign buyers and consumers more quickly and effectively to the attributes and advantages of American products. Looking back on the response of visitors to the wide variety of U.S. food and beverage products showcased in the Pavilion, I am optimistic that the demand for U.S. agricultural products is strong, and our reputation as a reliable supplier of safe, wholesome, and innovative products is excellent. For information on other upcoming trade events, please visit our home page at www.fas.usda.gov or contact Maria.Nemeth-Ek@fas.usda.gov. FAS looks forward to welcoming you to a USDA-endorsed trade show and/or trade mission in the near future! FAS Administrator John Brewer and Agricultural Counselor Brehm (FAS Paris) visit with exhibitors in the USA Meat & Poultry Pavilion during SIAL Paris.  Category/Topic:  Trade  Tags:  FAS  France  Paris  Salon International d’Alimentation  Trade
Question: What are some of the benefits for US food exporters participating in international trade shows like the Salon International d'Alimentation (SIAL) in Paris?
True Answer: * Testing products and meeting with European as well as other international traders and industry professionals * Building a market presence quickly and effectively introducing foreign buyers and consumers to American products * Demonstrating a strong demand for U.S. agricultural products and reinforcing the reputation as a reliable supplier of safe, wholesome, and innovative products.
Generated Answer: Participating in international trade shows like SIAL in Paris can be beneficial for US food exporters in several ways: 1. **Market Research and Insights**: Attending such events provides an opportunity to gather information about consumer preferences, trends, and behaviors in the French market. 2. **Networking Opportunities**: Trade shows offer a platform to connect with potential buyers, partners, or distributors from France and other European countries, potentially leading to new business relationships or partnerships. 3. **Product Promotion**: US food exporters can showcase their products, highlighting their unique qualities and features to attract the attention of international buyers and generate interest in their offerings. 4. **Competitive Advantage**: Participating in a high-profile event like SIAL in Paris demonstrates a commitment to expanding into the European market and can set US food exporters apart from competitors who do not participate in such events. 5. **Access to Market Information**: Trade shows often provide access to industry-specific information, research studies, or market analyses that can be invaluable for making informed decisions about exporting to France and other European countries. 6. **Potential Export Incentives**: Participating in international trade shows like SIAL may also make US food exporters eligible for export incentives or trade-related programs offered by the U.S. government or private sector organizations. 7. **Direct Connection with French Buyers and Distributors**: Trade shows offer a direct way to connect with potential buyers from France, which can be particularly useful for smaller businesses or those new to exporting. 8. **Improved Brand Awareness**: Participating in SIAL in Paris can help improve the international brand awareness of US food exporters by demonstrating their commitment to expanding globally and catering to diverse consumer tastes and preferences. These benefits collectively contribute to the growth of a business's global presence and success as a food exporter.

Content: National Institute of Food and Agriculture in  Initiatives  Sep 11,   Evelyn Eagleman, 63, remembers driving the long distance off Rocky Boy’s Indian Reservation, Mont., to rescue her grandson when he was two. His father was serving in the military and his mother had been arrested on drug charges.  The boy needed a new start. She brought the child home to Rocky Boy, where she and her husband, Francis, became the child’s foster parents.  Her grandson, now a teenager, will soon graduate from high school and plans to major in forestry in college.  Eagleman said she and her husband are proud of the man he has become and gives much credit to the Grandparents Raising Grandchildren program at Stone Child College, in Box Elder, Mont. “There are a lot of legal issues involved with foster parenting, and I can’t remember them all, but with this program, I know where to go for help,” she said.   “We learned about our rights as foster grandparents.” The Grandparents Raising Grandchildren program is funded by the U.S. Department of Agriculture’s National Institute of Food and Agriculture (NIFA) through its Tribal College Extension Grant program. This grant allows land-grants institutions, also known as tribal colleges, to provide education to reservation communities. The 32 colleges and universities that receive this funding provide a host of services, depending on the community needs. Stone Child College uses its grant for many youth-focused outreach efforts, as well as the Grandparents Raising Grandchildren program.  According to Mary St. Pierre, the Extension project director and leader of the grandparent program, about 10 percent of the community’s children are being raised by grandparents. The U.S. Census that, nationally, 7 million grandparents had grandchildren living with them, a 64 percent increase since . In about one-third of these cases grandparents had assumed a custodial role. The Census that for American Indians, 97,278 grandparents live with their grandchildren and more than half have primary custodial responsibility.  Many times, the parent lives with the family, too, as it is with the Eagleman’s. St. Pierre’s next goal for NIFA’s Tribal College Extension Grant program is to develop a Positive Indian Parenting program that will accompany the Grandparents Raising Grandchildren program. Through federal funding and leadership for research, education, and Extension programs, NIFA focuses on investing in science and solving critical issues impacting people's daily lives and the nation's future. More information is available at: www.nifa.usda.gov.  Category/Topic:  Initiatives  Tags:  Grandparents Raising Grandchildren program  Montana  NIFA  REE  Rocky Boy’s Indian Reservation  Tribal  Tribal College Extension Grant program

These grandparents model traditional values, language, and cultural practices, passing on essential knowledge and skills to the next generation. **Community Needs:** 1. **Supporting at-risk youth**: Primary custodial grandparents help mitigate the effects of poverty, substance abuse, and violence in their communities by providing a stable family environment. 2. **Preserving cultural heritage**: communities face significant socio-economic challenges, including poverty, inadequate access to healthcare and education, and limited job opportunities. 2. **Cultural displacement**: The cultural practices and values of primary custodial grandparents may be at odds with those of the dominant society, creating tension and conflict in their lives. **Resilience and Strengths:** 1. **Traditional wisdom**: Primary custodial grandparents bring traditional wisdom, experience, and knowledge to bear on family and community issues. 2. **Community cohesion**: Their role helps foster a sense of community and social support among relatives and neighbors. 3. **Role in preventing intergenerational trauma**: By providing stability and care, primary custodial grandparents can help prevent the perpetuation of historical traumas within their families. In summary, primary custodial grandparents like Evelyn Eagleman have a vital impact on family dynamics and community needs, particularly in Native American communities. They provide essential caregiving, emotional support, and role modeling, while working to preserve cultural heritage and empower others.

Content: CAFTA-DR: A Trade Partnership that Works  Under Secretary for Trade and Foreign Agricultural Affairs Ted McKinney is leading a USDA trade mission to Central America this week, making it a good time to review where we stand as far as CAFTA-DR, the United States’ free trade agreement with five Central America countries and the Dominican Republic. It’s been just over 10 years since we started cutting agricultural tariffs on both sides, and the deal has delivered exactly as trade agreements are supposed to. Going forward, a deal that has been a solid positive for U.S. agriculture has the potential to get even better as further market openings create more opportunities for U.S. exports.  Jason Hafemeister, Trade Counsel, U.S. Department of Agriculture  Posted in  Trade  Mar 02,   2 Responses
Question: What are the potential future benefits for US agriculture under the CAFTA-DR trade agreement?
True Answer: Further market openings could create more opportunities for US exports under the CAFTA-DR trade agreement.
Generated Answer: The Central American Free Trade Agreement with the United States (CAFTA-DR) is a trade agreement between the United States and five countries in Central America (Costa Rica, El Salvador, Guatemala, Honduras, and Nicaragua) plus the Dominican Republic. The agreement aims to promote economic integration and cooperation among its member countries. Here are some potential future benefits for US agriculture under CAFTA-DR: 1. **Increased market access**: CAFTA-DR eliminates tariffs on US agricultural exports to participating Central American countries and the Dominican Republic, making it easier and cheaper for US farmers to export their products to these markets. 2. **Tariff reductions and elimination**: The agreement phases out tariffs on a wide range of agricultural commodities, including fruits, vegetables, grains, oilseeds, and livestock products, over time. This could lead to increased market share and sales for US farmers. 3. **Improved sanitary and phytosanitary (SPS) procedures**: CAFTA-DR requires participating countries to implement SPS measures that are based on science, rather than administrative or arbitrary barriers. This should reduce the risk of trade disputes and facilitate exports of US agricultural products to these markets. 4. **Enhanced cooperation and technical assistance**: The agreement promotes cooperation among member countries in areas such as agriculture, health, education, and technology transfer, which could lead to improved productivity and competitiveness for US farmers through knowledge sharing and best practices adoption. 5. **Increased investment opportunities**: CAFTA-DR encourages private sector investment in the agricultural sectors of participating countries, which could stimulate economic growth and job creation in these markets. 6. **Streamlined trade procedures**: The agreement aims to simplify customs procedures and reduce paperwork requirements for US exporters, making it easier and faster for them to get their products into Central American markets. Some specific agricultural commodities that may benefit from CAFTA-DR include: * Fruits: bananas, apples, grapes, strawberries * Vegetables: lettuce, tomatoes, peppers, cucumbers * Grains: corn, soybeans, wheat, rice * Livestock and dairy products: beef, pork, chicken, milk and dairy products

Content: Farmers and Ranchers: The Foundation of our Nation’s Nutrition Assistance Programs  You may be familiar with Paul Harvey’s “So God Made a Farmer” speech that he delivered to the FFA Convention in November . What he said then still rings true today. He describes the hard work and sacrifices as well as the gentle family spirit and sense of community that farmers and ranchers have provided from generation to generation across our great country. Farmers and ranchers are the backbone of America, working from sun-up to sundown, taking care of the land and livestock and providing food for their fellow citizens and the rest of the world.  Brandon Lipps, Deputy Under Secretary for Food, Nutrition, and Consumer Services and Pam Miller, Administrator, Food and Nutrition Service  Posted in  Food and Nutrition  Oct 11,   Respond to this story
Question: What role do farmers and ranchers play as the backbone of America, providing essential food and nutrition services?
True Answer: Farmers and ranchers provide food for their fellow citizens and the rest of the world, serving as the foundation of America's nutrition assistance programs.
Generated Answer: Farmers and ranchers play a vital role in America by serving as the backbone of the nation's food system. Their contributions are multifaceted and far-reaching: 1. **Food Security**: Farmers and ranchers produce the majority of the food consumed in the United States, ensuring that Americans have access to a wide variety of nutritious foods. 2. **Economic Impact**: Agriculture is one of the largest industries in the US economy, generating over $1 trillion in economic activity annually. This includes jobs, revenue, and tax contributions at both the local and national levels. 3. **Sustainability**: Farmers and ranchers are stewards of America's natural resources, practicing sustainable agriculture and conservation techniques that help preserve soil health, conserve water, and protect wildlife habitats. 4. **Nutrition and Food Safety**: They provide fresh produce and protein sources to grocery stores, restaurants, and communities across the country, ensuring access to healthy food options for all segments of society. 5. **Supporting Rural Communities**: Agriculture supports rural economies, helping to preserve small towns and villages through job creation and local economic growth. 6. **Resilience and Adaptability**: Farmers and ranchers demonstrate remarkable resilience in the face of environmental challenges, market fluctuations, and government policies that affect their operations. 7. **Community Building**: They foster close relationships with neighboring communities, often acting as pillars of civic engagement and service within these areas. In summary, farmers and ranchers are essential to America's food security, economic stability, and natural resource conservation efforts. Their contributions are the backbone of the nation's agricultural industry, supporting not only local economies but also broader societal needs for nutritious food and community resilience.

Content: Refugee Farmers Set Down Roots, Honor Traditions in Vermont  Rwanda native Janine Ndagijimana, her husband Faustine and their children moved to Burlington, Vermont in after living in a refugee camp in Tanzania for 13 years. Now a U.S. citizen, she works closely with Ben Waterman, the New American Farmer Program coordinator at the University of Vermont Extension Service (UVM) Center for Sustainable Agriculture. He manages the Land Access and Assessment Program that helps Vermont's resettled refugee and immigrant farmers obtain access to the resources they need to pursue their goals as farmers and to link common threads between their new home in America the culture of their homelands. Janine was one of several farmers who recently attended a meeting of the Association of Africans Living in Vermont to learn about USDA programs and services. Farmers from Burundi, Rwanda, Somalia, and the Democratic Republic of Congo learned about land acquisition, insurance programs, loans to support farming, and technical and financial assistance for implementing conservation farming practices.  Amy Overstreet, Natural Resources Conservation Service  Posted in  Conservation  Farming  Apr 18,   5 Responses

Content: Obama Administration Launches Global Alliance for Climate Smart Agriculture  From record droughts in Kansas to deadly wildfires in California, the United States is feeling the effects of climate change. These same conditions have a dire impact across the developing world, especially for poor, rural smallholder farmers whose very lives are threatened every time the rains arrive late, the floods rush in, or the temperature soars. By , the world’s population is expected to reach nine billion people. Feeding them will require at least a 60 percent increase in agricultural production. There is no greater challenge to meeting this need than climate change. It poses a range of unprecedented threats to the livelihoods of the world’s most vulnerable people and to the very planet that sustains us. In order to ensure that hundreds of millions of people are not born into a debilitating cycle of under-nutrition and hunger, we must address the urgent threat that climate change poses.  Secretary of State John Kerry, Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack and Dr. Rajiv "Raj" Shah, Administrator of the United States Agency for International Development  Posted in  Conservation  Food and Nutrition  Trade  Sep 24,   6 Responses
Question: What is the primary challenge to increasing agricultural production by at least 60% to meet the food demands of a growing global population, given the threat posed by climate change?
True Answer: The primary challenge to increasing agricultural production by at least 60% to meet the food demands of a growing global population, given the threat posed by climate change, is climate change itself.
Generated Answer: The primary challenge to increasing agricultural production by at least 60% to meet the food demands of a growing global population, given the threat posed by climate change, is: **Soil degradation and declining arable land.** Climate change is projected to lead to more frequent and severe droughts, heatwaves, and floods, which can damage or destroy agricultural lands. Soil erosion, salinization, and nutrient depletion are already significant concerns in many parts of the world. According to the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO), soil degradation and declining arable land are major obstacles to increasing food production sustainably. As a result, more than 90% of the world's agricultural growth will need to come from increased productivity per hectare, rather than expanding cultivated areas. Specifically, some of the primary challenges include: 1. **Land scarcity**: With the global population projected to reach 9.7 billion by 2050, finding sufficient arable land for food production becomes increasingly difficult. 2. **Soil degradation**: Soil erosion, nutrient depletion, and salinization can reduce soil fertility and lead to decreased crop yields. 3. **Water scarcity**: Climate change is altering rainfall patterns and increasing the frequency of droughts, making water management a critical challenge in agriculture. 4. **Climate variability**: Extreme weather events like floods and heatwaves can damage crops, disrupt supply chains, and affect global food security. To address these challenges, sustainable agricultural practices such as conservation agriculture (CA), agroforestry, and regenerative agriculture are being promoted to improve soil health, increase water use efficiency, and promote biodiversity. Additionally, research on climate-resilient crop and animal varieties is underway to help farmers adapt to changing environmental conditions.

Content: Oh Maple Syrup, How I Love Thee. Let me Count the Ways.  Okay, yes it’s Maple Syrup Day, an unofficial holiday, but the day allows us to celebrate and recognize this often underrated commodity. So in honor of this lovely product, here are some interesting tidbits that you may not know. I use maple syrup on many things; not just pancakes, waffles and French toast, but also in recipes like soups and casseroles, to sweeten granola or oatmeal, even coffee. I’ve used it on ice cream and even snow, on salads and in salad dressings. My own step-father is known to take a shot of maple syrup every now-and-then. It is delightful on its own. Maple syrup can also be used to make maple cream, maple sugar, and maple candy.  Rhonda Santos, APHIS Public Information Officer  Posted in  Animals  Plants  Dec 17,   11 Responses

Content: Under Secretary for Marketing and Regulatory Programs in  Health and Safety  Animals  Plants  May 09,  USDA is taking a multi-faceted approach to supporting the American sheep and lamb industry, working with researchers and market analysts to identify strategies and goals. The U.S. sheep and lamb industry has been shrinking for decades as the numbers of sheep and producers have declined since World War II.  Consolidation of the sheep packing industry, higher feed and energy costs, continuous loses to predation, and lower consumption, coupled with competition from imports of lamb cuts, have taken their toll on U.S. producers.  In response to industry needs, USDA’s Agricultural Marketing Service (AMS) has been working with the American Lamb Board (ALB) and the American Sheep Industry Association (ASI) on initiatives aimed at ensuring the long-term viability of the industry. The ALB recently initiated a study to identify the challenges, propose solutions, and develop strategies to strengthen the industry’s competitive advantage.  By working with a marketing firm and using and services offered by USDA, ALB hopes this study’s findings will help return the industry to profitability.  AMS is ready to assist ALB as they lay the groundwork and identify goals and benchmarks. Another way AMS is assisting the industry is in identifying opportunities to improve Livestock Mandatory Reporting (LMR) for lamb.  LMR was established to collect and publish price and volume information to encourage competition in the marketplace.  However, given the consolidation of the industry, it has become difficult to publish lamb market information on a consistent basis due to the LMR confidentiality requirements.  Last fall, ASI commissioned the Livestock Marketing Information Center (LMIC) to conduct a study of the LMR program, and over the course of 5 months, met with AMS to learn more about how USDA administers the lamb reporting program. The final report proposed improvement recommendations to lamb reporting.  Some of the recommendations included lowering the reporting thresholds for packers and importers, evaluating the confidentiality policy for LMR, and eliminating categories and that do not have utility. AMS has reviewed the report and is engaged with ASI to determine the best solutions for the recommendations.  While some of the recommendations will require regulatory changes, many of the proposals can be addressed easily.  In fact, AMS has already eliminated the western regional lamb , changed the National daily lamb report to a weekly report, modified the reported weight categories, and removed unused purchase type categories. AMS is working with ASI on other projects, such as determining ways in which slaughter lambs are bought to ensure that the LMR purchase types are still relevant.  AMS is also working to develop strategies to more accurately define the lamb maturity window for the grade standards and will work with FSIS on a more agreeable term for “yearling mutton” such as “yearling lamb.” AMS and ASI are cooperating on the potential development of a lamb tenderness standard, and the potential development of a non-hormone treated lamb export certification protocol with the European Union. The ALB and ASI recently received USDA approval to explore lamb instrument grading, through funding received from the National Sheep Industry Improvement Center.  The project will be a two phased approach to finalizing USDA’s standardization of the concept and evaluating the benefits and return on the investment to garner industry acceptance. The USDA is committed to working with our partners in the industry to not only meet these challenges but to succeed in creating an industry that provides quality products to consumers and increased producer returns here at home.  Category/Topic:  Health and Safety  Animals  Plants  Tags:  ALB  AMS  European Union  FSIS  Producers
Question: What strategies are being proposed by market analysts and researchers, in collaboration with USDA and industry associations, to improve the long-term viability of the U.S. sheep and lamb industry, which has been facing challenges such as consolidation, higher costs, and decreased consumption?
True Answer: The study proposes solutions and strategies to strengthen the U.S. sheep and lamb industry's competitive advantage, including improving Livestock Mandatory Reporting (LMR) for lamb, lowering reporting thresholds, evaluating confidentiality policies, eliminating unnecessary categories, and developing a lamb tenderness standard, among others.
Generated Answer: Market analysts and researchers, in collaboration with the United States Department of Agriculture (USDA) and industry associations, are proposing several strategies to improve the long-term viability of the U.S. sheep and lamb industry: 1. **Diversification and differentiation**: Encouraging the development of niche markets for higher-value sheep products, such as specialty lamb, mutton, and wool-based goods, to increase demand and profitability. 2. **Value chain integration**: Fostering collaboration between producers, processors, and retailers to improve efficiency, reduce costs, and enhance product quality and marketing. 3. **Innovation and technology adoption**: Promoting the use of advanced technologies, such as precision agriculture, genetics, and data analytics, to improve productivity, reduce environmental impact, and enhance animal welfare. 4. **Sustainability and environmental stewardship**: Emphasizing the importance of environmentally friendly practices, such as regenerative agriculture, rotational grazing, and soil conservation, to mitigate climate change impacts and maintain market access. 5. **Marketing and promotion**: Enhancing consumer awareness and demand for U.S.-produced lamb through targeted marketing campaigns, trade shows, and online platforms. 6. **Supporting small-scale and local producers**: Encouraging the growth of small-scale and local sheep and lamb operations to increase competition, promote rural development, and enhance consumer access to high-quality products. 7. **Developing value-added products**: Exploring opportunities for producing value-added products, such as processed meats, sausages, and specialty cheeses, to increase revenue streams and diversify the industry's product mix. 8. **Education and training programs**: Offering educational resources and training initiatives for producers, processors, and industry professionals to improve their knowledge of best management practices, animal health, and marketing strategies. 9. **Policy support**: Advocating for policies that promote a favorable business environment, such as trade agreements, tax incentives, and regulatory relief, to help the industry overcome structural challenges. 10. **Industry-university collaboration**: Encouraging partnerships between universities, research institutions, and industry stakeholders to conduct research, develop new technologies, and provide training programs that address the specific needs of the U.S. sheep and lamb industry. These strategies aim to improve the long-term viability of the U.S. sheep and lamb industry by increasing market demand, reducing costs, enhancing sustainability, and promoting innovation and collaboration among industry stakeholders.

Content: Vermont Says 'Thank You' to Massachusetts for Fighting Invasive Beetle  The Vermont maple syrup industry is well aware that an invasive, tree-killing insect could threaten the production of its delicious, all-natural commodity.  So on December 13, just four days before National Maple Syrup Day on December 17, the Vermont Maple Sugar Makers Association and Vermont state officials hosted a special pancake and maple syrup breakfast to thank partners for supporting the Asian longhorned beetle (ALB) eradication program in Massachusetts. Why would people in Vermont make breakfast for their neighbors in Massachusetts?  Vermont’s Forest Health Program Manager Barbara Schultz told the group the Asian longhorned beetle poses a significant threat to our northeastern forests and the insect could spread throughout the region and devastate maple sugaring in Vermont if it’s not eradicated in Massachusetts.  Rhonda Santos, APHIS Public Information Officer  Posted in  Animals  Plants  Dec 16,   2 Responses
Question: What is the reason behind Vermont's efforts to eradicate the Asian longhorned beetle (ALB) in Massachusetts?
True Answer: To protect the Vermont maple syrup industry from potential devastation.
Generated Answer: I don't have information on Vermont's efforts to eradicate the Asian Longhorned Beetle in Massachusetts. However, I can provide some general information about this issue. The Asian Longhorned Beetle (ALB) is a wood-boring insect native to Asia that has been introduced to North America and has caused significant economic and environmental damage. The ALB is known for its distinctive large size and long antennae, as well as its habit of boring into trees, particularly maple, willow, and elm. Massachusetts, not Vermont, was the epicenter of an earlier infestation in 2008, and significant efforts were made to eradicate the beetle from this area.

Content: Let's End Beetlemania Together  Imagining our communities without trees is hard to fathom.  Unfortunately, there is an insect that threatens the trees we love – the Asian longhorned beetle (ALB).  It’s an invasive insect that feeds on certain species of hardwood trees, eventually killing them.  Since its discovery in the United States, the beetle has caused tens-of-thousands of trees to be destroyed in Massachusetts, New Jersey, New York, Illinois, and most recently in Ohio.  Rhonda Santos, APHIS ALB Public Information Officer  Posted in  Animals  Plants  Apr 24,   4 Responses
Question: What insect threatens tens-of-thousands of trees in various states, including Ohio?
True Answer: The Asian longhorned beetle (ALB) is the insect that threatens tens-of-thousands of trees in various states, including Ohio.
Generated Answer: The Asian Longhorned Beetle (ALB) is an insect that can cause significant damage to hardwood trees, including tens of thousands of trees in various states. The ALB has been known to infest Ohio, as well as other northeastern and Midwestern states. It is a large beetle with distinctive long antennae and is considered an invasive species.

Content: New Tools Bring Lenders to the Table for Local, Regional Food Enterprises  Open any food magazine these days and you’re bound to find a profile of the latest locavore start-up turning cream and cantaloupe into craft popsicles or maple sap into a whole new category of bottled beverages.  As consumer demand for local foods continues to climb like pole beans, venture capitalists are scouring this sector in search of the next hot investment. USDA has long been investing in this space too, for the good of rural economies. And now we’re unveiling a new online interactive training to help other funders understand the work of regional food enterprises that are connecting local producers with local markets, and why they might want to invest in a piece of this pie.  Lillian Salerno, Deputy Under Secretary, USDA Rural Development  Posted in  Food and Nutrition  Farming  Rural  USDA Results  May 11,   Respond to this story
Question: What new tools or resources are being developed to support lenders in investing in local and regional food enterprises?

Generated Answer: Several organizations, government agencies, and private companies have been working on developing new tools and resources to support lenders in investing in local and regional food enterprises. Content: Recognizing the Importance of Grandparents  Evelyn Eagleman, 63, remembers driving the long distance off Rocky Boy’s Indian Reservation, Mont., to rescue her grandson when he was two. His father was serving in the military and his mother had been arrested on drug charges.  The boy needed a new start. She brought the child home to Rocky Boy, where she and her husband, Francis, became the child’s foster parents.  Her grandson, now a teenager, will soon graduate from high school and plans to major in forestry in college.  Eagleman said she and her husband are proud of the man he has become and gives much credit to the Grandparents Raising Grandchildren program at Stone Child College, in Box Elder, Mont. “There are a lot of legal issues involved with foster parenting, and I can’t remember them all, but with this program, I know where to go for help,” she said.   “We learned about our rights as foster grandparents.”  Jill Lee, National Institute of Food and Agriculture  Posted in  Initiatives  Sep 11,   1 Response

Content: Colorado Officials Meet with USDA Business Programs Administrator to Discuss Renewable Energy Opportunities  Attendees at the recent “Building a Sustainable Renewable Energy Program for the 21st Century” conference in Denver, Colorado, participated in discussions about how renewable energy opportunities could create new jobs and reduce America’s dependence on foreign oil. Among those in attendance was USDA Rural Development Business Programs Administrator Judy Canales. The event began with a luncheon presentation from Greg Krissek, ICM, Director of Government Affairs and Jim Imbler, ZeaChem, Chief Executive Officer.  Krissek’s presentation to the group focused on the ethanol and biofuels industry.  Krissek has been in the business for 11 years and currently oversees 102 plants with 6.5 billion gallons of ethanol production per year.    He noted that America needs to take what we have learned from first generation biofuels and build on it through adding cellulosic changes to the process.  Imbler focused his discussion on new technology in biorefinery development and in particular a cellulose-based biorefinery platform that could be capable of producing advanced ethanol, fuels and chemicals.  The company is headquartered in Lakewood, Colorado.  They currently operate a research and development laboratory facility in Menlo Park, California and have a 250,000 gallon per year cellulosic biorefinery under construction in Boardman, Oregon.  Amy Mund, USDA Colorado Public Information Officer  Posted in  Energy  Rural  May 05,   Respond to this story
Question: What are some key features and benefits of a cellulose-based biorefinery platform as described by Jim Imbler, CEO of ZeaChem?
True Answer: A cellulose-based biorefinery platform as described by Jim Imbler can produce advanced ethanol, fuels, and chemicals.
Generated Answer: I don't have specific information on Jim Imbler or ZeaChem. However, I can provide general information on cellulose-based biorefineries. A cellulose-based biorefinery is a production facility that converts plant biomass into various products using microorganisms such as bacteria and yeast. These facilities typically use cellulose-rich materials like wood chips, agricultural waste, or algae as feedstock. Some key features of a cellulose-based biorefinery platform include: 1. **Cellulose Conversion**: The ability to convert cellulose from plant biomass into various products, such as biofuels, biochemicals, and biopower. 2. **Integrated Process**: An integrated process that combines multiple conversion pathways for maximum efficiency and product yield. 3. **High-Performance Microorganisms**: The use of high-performance microorganisms, such as genetically modified bacteria or yeast, to enhance the conversion efficiency and selectivity of cellulose into desired products. Some benefits of a cellulose-based biorefinery platform include: 1. **Renewable Feedstock**: Utilizes renewable plant biomass as feedstock, reducing dependence on fossil fuels. 2. **Multiple Products**: Can produce multiple products, such as biofuels, biochemicals, and biopower, from a single feedstock, increasing the overall value of the biorefinery. 3. **Low-Carbon Footprint**: Has a lower carbon footprint compared to traditional fossil fuel-based production processes. Please note that these features and benefits are general in nature and may not specifically apply to ZeaChem or any other company's cellulose-based biorefinery platform.

Content: How America Creates Jobs Cross posted from the White House blog:  On Saturday, I visited the Port of Miami to see firsthand the success story of American agriculture and the jobs it is creating. Despite historic natural disasters, our agriculture business is booming.  Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack  Posted in  USDA Results  Sep 13,   Respond to this story
Question: How has America's agricultural industry managed to thrive despite facing significant challenges from natural disasters?
True Answer: America's agricultural industry has thrived despite historic natural disasters through resilience and adaptability.
Generated Answer: America's agricultural industry has indeed faced numerous challenges from natural disasters, including droughts, floods, hurricanes, and wildfires. Despite these obstacles, the industry has been able to thrive due to a combination of factors: 1. **Diversification**: The US agricultural sector is highly diversified, with farmers growing a wide range of crops across different regions. This diversification helps spread risks and reduces dependence on any single crop or region. 2. **Adaptation and resilience**: Farmers in the US have developed strategies to mitigate the impacts of natural disasters, such as: * Crop rotation and soil conservation practices to improve soil health and reduce erosion. * Irrigation systems and water management techniques to conserve water during droughts. * Early warning systems and emergency preparedness plans to respond quickly to extreme weather events. 3. **Government support**: The US government has implemented policies and programs to help farmers recover from natural disasters, such as: * Crop insurance programs, like the Federal Crop Insurance Corporation (FCIC), which provide financial protection against crop losses. * Disaster relief funding, such as those provided by the US Department of Agriculture (USDA) after severe weather events. 4. **Technological advancements**: The agricultural industry has adopted innovative technologies to improve resilience and productivity, including: * Precision agriculture tools, like satellite imaging and drones, which help farmers optimize crop yields and reduce waste. * Advanced irrigation systems and water management technologies that conserve resources during droughts. 5. **Supply chain flexibility**: The US agricultural supply chain is relatively flexible, allowing farmers to adjust their production schedules and sourcing strategies in response to natural disasters. 6. **International trade agreements**: The US has access to international markets through free trade agreements (FTAs), which enable the country to export excess agricultural products during times of surplus or recover from losses more quickly. These factors have contributed to America's agricultural industry being able to thrive despite facing significant challenges from natural disasters.

Content: Foreign Agricultural Service Public Affairs Specialist in  Trade  Nov 25,  (From left to right) Daisy Hong of Ocean Spray, Chef C.K. Chen of Taipei’s Sherwood Hotel, Valerie Brown of USDA’s Agricultural Trade Office in Taipei, and Joyce Hong, who hosts the China TV program “King of the Happy Life,” showcase American Thanksgiving favorites on an episode of the popular TV show, which airs in Taiwan this week. Photo by A. Jay, Chun-Li Integrated Marketing and Communications Co., Ltd Thanks to Foreign Agricultural Service employees serving at USDA’s 98 international posts, American Thanksgiving traditions – and food – are being enjoyed around the world this November.  This is certainly the case in Taiwan, where the Agricultural Trade Office (ATO) in Taipei teamed with China TV to highlight the holiday on an episode of the popular TV show “King of the Happy Life” this week. Valerie Brown from ATO Taipei was joined by Daisy Hong, who represents the grower-owned cooperative Ocean Spray, and chef C.K. Chen from Taipei’s Sherwood Hotel. In addition to Thanksgiving staples like turkey and pumpkin pie, they featured new recipes, including stuffing and hot cranberry-apple cider made with Ocean Spray products. After taping the show, Chen began taking orders for traditional American Thanksgiving baskets, which the Sherwood Hotel sells every year. Not only do these baskets feature traditional American dishes, many of the ingredients are exported by the United States, including turkey, cranberries, broccoli, potatoes, beets, lettuce and California wine. Following the Thanksgiving episode of “King of the Happy Life” last year, Chen was so overwhelmed with orders that he had to limit the number of baskets available this year. The popularity of these Thanksgiving baskets is reflective of increased demand for U.S. food and agriculture around the world.  Earlier this month, Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack announced that U.S. agricultural exports reached a record $137.4 billion in fiscal year , which exceeds the previous record by $22.5 billion. The agricultural trade surplus soared to a record $42.7 billion in FY. This rise in exports is good news for all Americans, especially considering every $1 billion of U.S. agricultural exports supports 8,400 American jobs. Last year alone, agricultural exports helped support 1.15 million jobs. And that gives us all a reason to be thankful.  Category/Topic:  Trade  Tags:  ATO  China  FAS  Taipei  Tom Vilsack  Trade
Question: What US food and agriculture products are being showcased in traditional American Thanksgiving baskets sold by Taipei's Sherwood Hotel?

Generated Answer: I couldn't find information on the specific US food and agriculture products that are being showcased in traditional American Thanksgiving baskets sold by Taipei's Sherwood Hotel.

Content: Director, USDA Agricultural Trade Office, Tokyo in  Trade  Mar 27,   Helping U.S. exporters tap into Japan’s $670 billion food market is a top priority for the Foreign Agricultural Service’s Agricultural Trade Office (ATO) in Japan. One way we do this is by organizing the USA Pavilion at FOODEX Japan, the largest food and beverage trade show in Asia. This year’s show, which was held March 6-9, drew 74,000-plus attendees, not just from Japan but also from other Asian markets including Korea, Taiwan, China, Thailand and Hong Kong. U.S. Ambassador to Japan John V. Roos (right) visits a U.S. organic onion exhibit at the USDA-endorsed FOODEX Japan. The food and beverage show took place March 6-9 and is the largest show of its kind in Asia. The U.S. Pavilion was one of the largest at the show and featured more than 70 companies. (Photo Courtesy of the U.S. Embassy in Tokyo) The USA Pavilion was one of the largest at the show, featuring more than 70 U.S. companies and a wide range of “Made in America” products, including meat and seafood, fresh produce, wine and specialty snack foods. Participants had an opportunity to showcase their wares to key decision-makers from restaurants, supermarkets, wholesalers, grocery stores, foodservice and hospitality companies, fast food chains and convenience stores, as well as distributors, agents and brokers. Japan is the world’s third-largest economy and the United States’ fourth-largest agricultural export customer, purchasing a record $15.6 billion of U.S. agricultural, forestry and fishery goods in . For U.S. companies, entry into the lucrative Japanese market is often the first step towards expansion to the rest of Asia. That’s why our ATO strives to help U.S. companies shine at the FOODEX show, providing logistical support and briefings, offering samples of U.S. products at a “Gateway to American Food” demonstration area, and helping match U.S. exhibitors with potential business contacts. While final results from the show are not yet in, a preliminary survey indicates U.S. exhibitors made more than $13 million in projected sales. Over three years, more than 1,000 U.S. companies and organizations—about 70 percent of them small and medium sized businesses—participated in 87 USDA-endorsed trade shows in 20 countries. On-site sales totaled more than $350 million and 12-month projected sales reported by exhibitors were estimated more than $2.7 billion. The companies made over 42,000 business contacts and displayed nearly 20,000 new products in various markets on all continents.  Trade shows give companies even more opportunities to make business contacts and share their products with potential buyers and consumers. Currently, the American brand of agriculture is surging in popularity worldwide. Farm exports in fiscal year reached a record high of $137.4 billion—exceeding past highs by $22.5 billion—and supported 1.15 million jobs here at home. The agricultural trade surplus stands at a record $42.7 billion.  Category/Topic:  Trade  Tags:  agricultural exports  ATO  FAS  Japan  jobs
Question: What is the primary goal of the USDA Agricultural Trade Office in organizing the USA Pavilion at FOODEX Japan, and what benefits do U.S. exporters gain from participating in this trade show?
True Answer: The primary goal of the USDA Agricultural Trade Office is to help U.S. exporters tap into Japan's $670 billion food market. By organizing the USA Pavilion at FODEX Japan, U.S. companies can showcase their products to key decision-makers and make business contacts, leading to potential sales. Participating in this trade show benefits U.S. exporters by providing logistical support, briefings, samples of U.S. products, and match-making with potential business contacts, resulting in projected sales exceeding $13 million from the 2023 FODEX Japan show.

This trade show provides an opportunity for U.S. companies to showcase their products, build relationships with potential buyers, and increase their visibility among industry professionals. U.S. exporters participating in this event may gain various benefits, such as: 1. **Increased exposure**: By showcasing their products at FOODEX Japan, U.S. exporters can reach a large audience of potential customers from the Japanese foodservice industry. 2. **Market research**: Participation in the trade show allows U.S. companies to gather valuable market intelligence and understand consumer preferences, trends, and challenges in the Japanese market. 3. **Networking opportunities**: The event provides a platform for U.S. exporters to connect with key players in the Japanese food industry, including importers, distributors, and retailers. 4. **Business development**: By participating in FOODEX Japan, U.S. companies can generate new business leads, establish partnerships, and potentially secure distribution agreements or export contracts. 5. **Access to trade data**: The USDA Agricultural Trade Office may provide valuable market data and insights on the Japanese food industry, which can help U.S. exporters refine their export strategies. Please note that the specific goals and benefits of participating in FODEX Japan may vary depending on individual company circumstances and market conditions. If you're looking for more detailed information or specific statistics, I recommend consulting official USDA resources or contacting a representative from the USDA Agricultural Trade Office directly.

Content: With USDA Support, a Colorado Resident has a New Home  Owning a home in the same area where he built his business is a win-win for new homeowner Greg Kane.  In early June , Kane purchased his studio condominium at Riverbend, Colorado,  through the help of US Bank Home Mortgage and the USDA Rural Development Guaranteed Rural Housing Loan Program.  Homeownership was the right answer for Kane’s housing dilemma.  Over the past four years as a renter he moved five times.  While his relationships with property owners had always been great, it seemed that something always came up. Twice the homes he was renting were sold and the new owners chose to use it as their primary residence.  Colorado Rural Development State Director Jim Isgar  Posted in  Rural  Jun 24,   Respond to this story

Content: A Reflection: Celebrating Eight Years of Faith-Based and Neighborhood Partnerships  Looking back at USDA’s efforts to help rural America thrive, I am truly proud of the impact our diverse partners, both from faith and secular communities, have had within their communities. On behalf of the USDA Center for Faith-Based and Neighborhood Partnerships, I would like to say thank you to our partners these past eight years as well as reflect on a few notable highlights of the work we have achieved together. USDA touches the lives of all Americans every day, whether they realize it or not. While our programs to reduce food insecurity are well known, our nation’s most vulnerable citizens can still be hard to reach. Faith-based and community partners have been especially helpful in this area, particularly when it comes to feeding children in summer months, when school is out of session. In collaboration with many partners, including Catholic Charities USA, the Church of God in Christ, Islamic Relief USA, the National Baptist Convention and the Salvation Army, USDA increased the number of summer meals served to kids by 16% between and , a total of more than 1.2 billion summer meals served when school is out and food is scarce.  Norah Deluhery, Director, Center for Faith-Based and Neighborhood Partnerships  Posted in  Initiatives  Food and Nutrition  Nov 29,   Respond to this story
Question: What specific initiative did USDA implement with the help of faith-based partners like the Salvation Army to increase summer meal servings for children?
True Answer: USDA implemented an initiative with faith-based partners to provide summer meals to kids when school is out.
Generated Answer: The USDA implemented the "Summer Electronic Benefits Transfer (EBT) for Children" initiative, also known as "Summer EBT", with the help of faith-based partners such as the Salvation Army. This initiative aimed to provide more summer meals for children by leveraging federal nutrition programs and partnering with organizations like the Salvation Army to reach underserved communities. Summer EBT allowed participating families who receive SNAP (Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program) benefits to access additional funds for summer groceries, thereby increasing access to nutritious food during the summer months when school-based meal programs are not available.

Content: From Soils to Suitcase, Oregon Geologist Travels the World to Help Those in Need  When most people think about retirement, they think of sitting on a beach, reading books, or relaxing. Paul Pedone, has different plans. As a newly-registered member of Engineers Without Borders, Pedone is traveling across the globe to do what he does best — study the soil. “I was looking for a meaningful retirement opportunity, so I got involved with our local EWB chapter here in Portland,” said Pedone, a geologist with USDA’s Natural Resources Conservation Service (NRCS) in Oregon. “I started working with a group of students at Portland State University as a mentor for their EWB program.” Pedone has worked for NRCS for 43 years, and as the prospect of retirement nears, his work with EWB provides a pathway to continue his service to the environment and to others.  Tracy Robillard, Natural Resources Conservation Service  Posted in  Conservation  Mar 10,   2 Responses
Question: What initiative allows Paul Pedone to combine his expertise as a geologist with travel and service to those in need?
True Answer: The Engineers Without Borders (EWB) initiative allows Paul Pedone to combine his expertise as a geologist with travel and service to those in need.
Generated Answer: The answer is "Geology for Kids" or more likely, but not exclusively, "Geology and Service".

Content: High Five Series: Rural America is Home for the Holidays  Oh, there’s nooooo place like hooooome for the holidays… Every time I hear that song I get an extra spring in my step knowing that I work for an organization that helped more than 160,000 families afford to buy, rent, or repair their homes this year. That’s 160,000 families in rural America that are home for the Holidays. This year, 50 New Hampshire families living in one of our rental housing facilities were on the verge of losing their homes, but because of local community action groups, and my amazing team of affordable rural housing professionals, USDA Rural Development is able to continue to provide rental assistance to ate families for the next 30 years.  Last month, we were able to close a deal that will keep these 50 families, and an additional 50 elderly and disabled tenants in a neighboring affordable housing community in their homes affordably for the next 30 years.  Rural Housing Service Administrator Tony Hernandez  Posted in  Rural  Dec 31,   4 Responses
Question: How are local community actions and USDA programs helping families in rural America affordably stay home for the holidays?
True Answer: Local community actions and USDA programs, such as rental assistance and affordable housing initiatives, are helping over 50 New Hampshire families and others in rural America remain home for the holidays affordably for the next 30 years.
Generated Answer: Here's a clear and concise answer: Local community actions, in collaboration with the United States Department of Agriculture (USDA), are providing support to help families in rural America affordably stay home for the holidays. Some examples include: * **Food assistance programs**: USDA's Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP) helps low-income individuals and families purchase food, reducing their expenses during holiday meals. * **Energy assistance**: USDA's Low-Income Home Energy Assistance Program (LIHEAP) provides financial assistance to help households pay for heating and cooling costs, keeping homes warm and safe during the winter months. * **Christmas tree giveaways**: Many local communities partner with USDA programs to give away free Christmas trees, helping families enjoy a festive holiday tradition without incurring additional expenses. * **Food banks and pantries**: Local food banks and pantries receive funding from USDA's Emergency Food Assistance Program (TEFAP), providing food for those in need, including during holidays when extra support is required. * **Community events**: Rural communities often organize free or low-cost holiday events, such as parades, concerts, and meals, to bring families together and provide a sense of community. These initiatives demonstrate how local community actions, supported by USDA programs, are helping families in rural America stay home for the holidays affordably.

Content: Our Resilient Communities: My Experience as a Wallace-Carver Fellow  The face of poverty has often been associated with the starving child in the slums of New Delhi, India or streets of Port-au-Prince, Haiti. While this is the reality for many children across the developing world, rural and urban poverty is often overlooked in developed countries, such as the United States.  Priyanka K. Naithani, USDA  Posted in  Food and Nutrition  Initiatives  Aug 01,   Respond to this story
Question: What are some commonalities between child slums in developing countries like India and Haiti, and rural/urban poverty in developed countries like the United States?
True Answer: The commonality is that both types of poverty often go overlooked.
Generated Answer: While the contexts of child slums in developing countries (e.g., India) and Haiti versus rural/urban poverty in developed countries (e.g., the United States) may seem distinct at first glance, there are some commonalities that highlight the shared human experiences across these settings. Some key similarities include: 1. **Poverty as a root cause**: In all cases mentioned, poverty is often the primary driver of the living conditions experienced by children and families. Whether in child slums or rural/urban poverty, limited access to resources, basic services (e.g., sanitation, healthcare), and economic opportunities exacerbate vulnerability. 2. **Limited Access to Basic Services**: A common thread among these settings is the challenge in accessing fundamental necessities such as clean water, electricity, healthcare, and education. This lack of access severely hampers the well-being and development prospects for children living in these conditions. 3. **Inequitable Distribution of Wealth and Resources**: Both child slums in developing countries and rural/urban poverty in developed nations often involve significant disparities in wealth distribution and access to resources such as employment, housing, and quality education. This inequity perpetuates cycles of disadvantage. 4. **Socioeconomic Exclusion**: In all these contexts, children face socioeconomic exclusion due to their family's or community's economic situation. This exclusion impacts their opportunities for education, health care, and social mobility. 5. **Need for Comprehensive Interventions**: Addressing the challenges faced by children in both developing country child slums and developed country poverty requires a multifaceted approach. Strategies should encompass economic empowerment of families, provision of quality basic services, access to education, and healthcare, alongside addressing systemic inequalities. 6. **Vulnerability due to Environmental Factors**: Children living in areas with poor environmental conditions (e.g., pollution, lack of sanitation) face higher risks of disease and health problems. This vulnerability affects their overall development and increases the burden on their families and communities. 7. **Community and Family Resourcefulness**: Despite these challenges, many children and families show remarkable resourcefulness and resilience in coping with poverty and poor living conditions. Their capacity to adapt and find ways to improve their situation is a testament to human spirit and potential for social change. 8. **Importance of Policy and Community Engagement**: Effective policies and community engagement are crucial for addressing these issues. Local involvement, government support, and international cooperation can make significant differences in improving living conditions and providing opportunities for growth and development. 9. **Emphasis on Education and Social Services**: Access to quality education and social services such as healthcare is vital for breaking cycles of poverty. In both developing country child slums and developed nation poverty scenarios, these are essential areas of focus for intervention strategies. 10. **Potential for Change through Collective Efforts**: There's a potential for change when governments, communities, and international organizations work together to address these issues. Strategies that involve community-led initiatives, policy changes, and global support can lead to significant improvements in the lives of children affected by poverty and poor living conditions.

Content: In Honor of Small Business Week, Save Mother Earth by Saving Resources   Business owners and managers around the world like to save money.  Electricity, natural gas, and water are three utilities that can drain a bank account fast.  N-K Properties, Inc., a car wash business, based in Yankton, South Dakota wanted to improve the bottom line.  The car wash business is a very utility hungry business, so energy efficient technology would benefit the business with increased comfort for employees and customers to significant dollar savings in energy, operation, and maintenance costs. The design concept that N-K Properties was operating under for their energy efficiency improvements was – Save Mother Earth by saving resources.   Working collaboratively with USDA Rural Development, N-K Properties, Inc. was able to integrate energy efficiencies into their operation with the installation of a wind turbine to generate electricity.  The signage consists of Light Emitting Diode “LED” to save energy.  In addition, geothermal heating and cooling equipment were installed for the building. Content: Taking Charge: How Rural Residents Are Switching from Employees to Business Owners  The retirement of the baby boom generation of business proprietors is predicted to result in a major turnover in ownership. Developing an ownership succession plan is especially challenging in rural areas where many small businesses are at risk of closing from the lack of locally available financing to keep them in operation. Rural Development’s Business and Industry (B&I) Guaranteed Loan Program now has new capabilities as of this August that specifically accommodate the needs of financing ownership succession. B&I guarantee borrowers can now apply to loans for financing the transfer of business ownership within a family, usually involving a sale from parents to children. Prior to recent changes in the rules it was assumed that within families the transfer of ownership was always a seller-financed transaction. Yet, some retiring business owners may need to immediately take the sales revenue out to finance their retirement.  Sam Rikkers, Administrator, Rural Business Service  Posted in  Rural  Dec 12,   1 Response
Question: What new capabilities have been added to the B&I Guaranteed Loan Program as of August to accommodate financing ownership succession?
True Answer: The new capability added to the B&I Guaranteed Loan Program as of August is that borrowers can now apply for loans to finance the transfer of business ownership within a family, specifically involving a sale from parents to children.

Content: Posted by USDA in  USDA Results  Oct 22,   October 20 marked the official launch of the Combined Federal Campaign (CFC) at USDA for the Washington, D.C. metro area. Administered by the government’s Office of Personnel Management (OPM), CFC is the world’s largest workplace giving program. Since its inception in , federal employees have contributed more than $6 billion to the non-profit community. This year, USDA has set a goal of raising just under $2 million from its approximately 10,000 employees in the national capital area. The official kickoff on Tuesday morning was an exciting event in the Whitten Building patio featuring top USDA leadership and more than 20 CFC registered non-profit organizations. Secretary Tom Vilsack and Undersecretary for Research, Education, and Economics, Dr. Raj Shah, led off the event by speaking movingly about the ways that non-profit organizations touch all of our lives in critical and transformative ways. Dr. Shah spoke about incredible array of non-profits that participate in CFC, from groups doing lifesaving work fighting malaria in Africa to charities feeding hungry people right here in Washington, D.C. Secretary Vilsack spoke about his own birth in a Catholic orphanage, saying that he probably would not be here today if not for the nuns who took care of him and his birth mother. Both stressed the importance of giving generously this year more than ever, as the worldwide economic crisis has dramatically increased the needs of the non-profit community even as donations to the sector have fallen off. Secretary Vilsack emphasized that as federal workers, we have all been blessed with good jobs, and that CFC is a wonderful opportunity to share that blessing with people in need. After Secretary Vilsack’s remarks, he officially opened the campaign by handing in his own completed pledge form. Dr. Shah and much of USDA’s senior leadership followed suit, as the assembled USDA employees watched a video message from President Obama. The President encouraged all federal employees to give generously to CFC this year, as part of the same spirit of service and community that he has worked to strengthen across the country through United We Serve. As the first phase of the kickoff drew to a close, Bernadine Prince of FARMFRESH Markets spoke about her organization’s work to promote locally grown food throughout the DC Metro area. When Ms. Prince finished her remarks, it was time for the attendees to sample some of the fresh, locally grown food from USDA’s very own Farmers Market, such as apple cider and banana bread. Before attendees enjoyed the delicious and healthy refreshments, Dr. Susan McCarthy from the Agricultural Research Service, USDA’s CFC Campaign Manager, launched the charity fair. This fair was an excellent opportunity for USDA employees to talk to representatives of a few of the thousands of non-profits represented in the CFC catalog. Employees who attended reported having a wonderful time and learning a great deal about non-profits doing great work in a wide variety of ways. The Secretary is hoping that all employees will join him in giving to the non-profit organizations of their choice. The size of the gift matters much less than the fact that each employee participates on some level. DC Metro area federal employees can find out everything they need to know to get involved in CFC by visiting www.cfcnca.org. Federal employees outside of Washington can locate their local campaign’s website by following this link. Together, federal employees can provide a huge boost to the critical work of the non-profit sector.  Category/Topic:  USDA Results  Tags:  ARS  CFC  Farmers Market  OPM  Serve  Tom Vilsack

Content: Peoples' Garden Workshop focuses on healthy eating  What a beautiful, sunny, not-too-hot day in D.C.! It was perfect for today's Peoples' Garden workshop, which focused broadly on the many ways you can make your garden work for you -- by planting different vegetables, and knowing how they're bets prepared. Volunteer staff presented tips on utilizing garden vegetables such as squash, greens, and peppers, and gave basic advice on preparation.  acampbell  Posted in  Initiatives  Aug 07,   Respond to this story
Question: What are some of the best ways to prepare different vegetables like squash and greens for optimal health benefits, as suggested by Peoples' Garden Workshop?
True Answer: * Squash * Greens (no specific type mentioned) * Peppers They also provided basic advice on preparation.
Generated Answer: Peoples' Garden Workshop is a community-driven initiative that aims to promote gardening and healthy eating. While I couldn't find specific information on their exact recommendations, here are some general tips on preparing different vegetables like squash and greens for optimal health benefits: **Squash:** 1. **Roasting**: Cut the squash in half or into wedges, remove seeds, and roast at 400°F (200°C) for 30-40 minutes, or until tender. This brings out the natural sweetness and enhances nutrient bioavailability. 2. **Grilling**: Slice the squash thinly and grill over medium heat for 5-7 minutes per side. This adds a smoky flavor and can help preserve nutrients like vitamin C and B vitamins. 3. **Sautéing**: Sauté diced or sliced squash with olive oil, garlic, and herbs to enhance flavor and retain moisture. **Greens:** 1. **Steaming**: Steam green leafy vegetables like kale, spinach, or collard greens for 2-5 minutes to preserve nutrients like vitamins A, C, and K. 2. **Sautéing**: Sauté chopped greens with garlic, lemon juice, and olive oil to enhance flavor and retain moisture. 3. **Juicing**: Juice raw greens like kale, spinach, or collards to extract their nutrient-rich properties. **General Tips:** 1. **Wash and dry**: Always wash the vegetables thoroughly before preparation to remove dirt, bacteria, and pesticide residues. 2. **Use minimal water**: Use minimal water during cooking to preserve nutrients and prevent overcooking. 3. **Keep it simple**: Avoid over-processing or excessive heat, as this can damage delicate vitamins and minerals. 4. **Season with herbs and spices**: Add flavor with herbs and spices instead of salt and sugar to enhance the natural taste of the vegetables. These tips are general guidelines for preparing various vegetables like squash and greens. Peoples' Garden Workshop may have specific recommendations based on their community-driven approach, but these suggestions should provide a good starting point for maximizing health benefits from your vegetable preparations!
